Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Seismic deployment in response to the 2018 Kilauea Lower East Rift Zone eruption and summit explosions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2018 Kilauea volcano eruptive activities provide a rare opportunity to study the dynamic process of a volcano eruption and image the detailed magma plumbing system. In this RAPID seismic deployment project, the investigators plan to deploy a temporary seismometer array around the Kilauea volcano system including the summit within the Hawaii Volcanoes National Park and lower east rift zone in the Puna District of Hawaii. The data recorded by the seismometers will help improve knowledge on how magma moves underground and its eruption process at the surface. The ongoing Kilauea volcanic activity produces a continuous threat to the residents and visitors of the Big Island of Hawaii. A better understanding of the magma pathways, the current status of the magma body, and the dynamic process associated with the volcanic activity will help USGS and local authorities to better develop future mitigation plans. The researchers will work closely with the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory and Hawaii Volcanoes National Park to conduct the experiment and disseminate the scientific findings through their education and outreach programs to their over 2 million annual visitors.

The goal of this RAPID proposal is to deploy a dense array of geophones on the southern region of the Big Island of Hawaii in response to the recent Kilauea volcanic activity. The reserachers propose to deploy three separate arrays that will cover the Kilauea summit, the Lower East Rift Zone (LERZ), and the area in between these two regions. The investigators plan to deploy ~110 autonomous three component Zland geophones to record continuous seismic signals for 30 days. Combined with the existing permanent seismic network, better earthquake and tremor source locations as well as 4D subsurface structure can be determined. The experiment should provide an unprecedented dataset to study Kilauea's volcanic plumbing system and magma migration. The raw seismic waveforms collected through the experiment will be archived at the IRIS DMC and distributed to the scientific community for analysis and redistribution immediately following the conclusion of the experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Immediately following the 2018 Kilauea volcano eruption, a temporal dense seismic array with 81 stations was deployed between June 15 and July 26 across the volcano system on the Big Island of Hawaii. The experiment, supported by this NSF RAPID grant and assisted by the USGS Hawaiian Volcano Observatory (HVO), was designed to record unprecedented seismic data during the major volcanic eruption that will lead to better understanding of subsurface magma plumbing structure and volcano eruption dynamics. In particular, a dense linear subarray was deployed across the Lower East Rift Zone (LERZ) near Leilani Estates, which was heavily damaged by the fissure magma fountaining. Another dense subarray was deployed partially surrounding the Kilauea summit, where the magma level within the Halemaumau Crater was actively retreating, which lead to episodic summit collapsing events. Besides one station, which was burnt by the adjacent lava flow, data from all other 80 stations were safely retrieved and are now archived at the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology Data Management Center (IRIS DMC; https://doi.org/10.7914/SN/Z1_2018).

 

In addition to the 2018 experiment, a follow up experiment was conducted between March 08 and April 22, 2019. 50 stations were again deployed across the Kilauea volcano system with a majority of the stations reoccupying sites in the LERZ and nearby the summit from the 2018 deployment. The goal of the experiment was to collect data within a short period right after the eruption so that co-eruption and post-eruption signals can be compared, and temporal structural variations can be studied. During the 2019 experiment, with additional support from the University of Utah (UU) and help from HVO, a geological field trip was conducted where three early career UU faculty lead a group of diverse UU students (including 3 undergraduate and 7 graduate students) to learn the geological structure associated with the volcanos across the Big Island.
